questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You create a transport rule as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Audit: The actions that the rule would have taken are written to the message tracking log, but no any action is taken on the message that would impact delivery.

AuditAndNotify: The rule operates the same as in Audit mode, but notifications are also enabled.
The message will be delivered. The Action is NOT Enforce

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
Ten days ago, a user named User1 sent an email message to a user named User2.
User2 never received the message.
You need to identify whether the message was delivered to User2.
What should you run from Exchange Management Shell?

discussion.content: the question doesnt ask what needs to be done first so I think the given answer is correct
In order to run 'Get-MessageTrackingReport', you require the message tracking report ID for which the command 'Search-MessageTrackingReport' has to be executed first.

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory forest. The forest contains two Active Directory sites named Site1 and Site2.
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization that contains a database availability group (DAG) named DAG1. DAG1 has three member servers in each site.
You need to prevent users from Site1 from sending email messages larger than 5 MB to the mailboxes in Site2.
What should you do?

choices.B: From Site1, create a custom Send connector, and then modify the address space.
choices.A: Modify the properties of the Active Directory site link.
choices.C: From Site2, create a custom Receive connector, and then modify the remote IP address range.

discussion.content: Answer should be C. Changing address space on a send connector would scope that connector to recipient domain, not destination site/server

I think the answer is the first one using
set-adsitelink -MaxMessageSize 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/set-adsitelink?view=exchange-ps

the answer should be to create send connector and modify -MaxMessageSize

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/new-sendconnector?view=exchange-ps

No one from the answers are valid at all

comments.content: This analysis is correct, it is not clear because said "modified the address space" but others are not posible anwers, then B

discussion.content:
- No DAG parameter for message size : Not D
- AD site link does have parameter for message size but this will impact both sites ! Not only Site1 : Not A
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/active-directory/set-adsitelink?view=exchange-ps

- Target is to prevent Site1 users from sending messages larger than 5MB, NOT Site2 users to receive such a message ! The filter must be based on Message size not on sender IPs. Not C
- Send connector properties do have separate settings for both Address space and MaxMessageSize. You won't set message size in Address space parameter ! 
The only remaining choice is B but it's a bit ambiguous.
But What' s the correct answer? B or C?

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Your company has a Microsoft Exchange Online subscription for an email domain named contoso.com.
The company works with a partner company that uses an email domain named tailspintoys.com.
You need to configure the environment only to accept email from tailspintoys.com if the email is sent from an IP address of 131.107.12.85.
How should you configure the connector from the Exchange admin center? To answer, drag the appropriate options to the correct message settings. Each option may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

choices.D: Stop the Microsoft Exchange Information Store service.
choices.B: Move the arbitration mailboxes to another server.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization that contains four Mailbox servers.
You are decommissioning a Mailbox server named EX01.
When you attempt to remove one of the mailbox databases from EX01, you receive a warning message that the database still contains mailboxes.
You run Get-Mailbox ""Server EX01 and confirm that all user mailboxes are hosted on other servers.
You need to remove the mailbox database.
What should you do first?

discussion.content:
The Exchange System (Arbitration) Mailboxes, like ‘Discovery Search’ are created on the first Exchange server installed in the organization. If you need to remove a database or uninstall Exchange you will need to move the arbitration mailboxes to a different database or different server, respectively.
https://enterpriseit.co/microsoft-exchange/how-to-find-and-move-the-exchange-arbitration-mailboxes/
